summary: This document is an email summary of a Webex meeting with Philip Fanara, an AT&T trial analyst and records custodian, discussing his review of a wireless billing statement (likely from 2004) and his potential testimony regarding AT&T's record-keeping practices. It appears to be part of legal discovery or preparation for a case involving phone records.

persons.name: Philip Fanara
persons.role: AT&T Trial Analyst and Testifying Records Custodian
persons.context: He is the subject of the Webex meeting, providing expertise on AT&T's business practices, record-keeping, and analysis of a wireless billing statement, likely in preparation for legal testimony.

events.title: Webex Meeting with Philip Fanara
events.description: A Webex meeting was held with Philip Fanara to discuss his review of a wireless billing statement (likely from 2004) and his expertise as an AT&T records custodian, in preparation for potential testimony.

keyFacts: Philip Fanara worked at AT&T for about 24 years, with the last 8 years as a testifying records custodian and the title 'Trial Analyst'.
Fanara is familiar with AT&T's business practices both currently and in 2004, and indicated that AT&T generally keeps records for at least 6-7 years.
The document discusses a wireless billing statement (referred to as 'GX') that appears to be from 2004, containing call details like date/time, numbers, minutes, and charges.
Fanara stated that the billing statement does not appear to be modified or altered, and that AT&T captures call information at or near the time of the call and maintains it in a database.
The email is subject to a protective order, indicating it contains sensitive or confidential information related to legal proceedings.
